questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents after falling on her outstretched hand. She complains of pain, swelling, and deformity near the wrist. X-ray shows a dorsally displaced, angulated distal radius fracture with radial shortening. After closed reduction, she is placed in a dorsal slab. During follow-up, she develops wrist stiffness and persistent burning pain in her hand. Which of the following is not a known complication of her condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gunstock deformity is not a complication of Colles fracture; it is seen in supracondylar fractures of the humerus.

Colles fracture, a dorsally displaced distal radius fracture common in elderly women following FOOSH (fall on outstretched hand), has several complications:

  • Non-union is rare in Colles fracture but has been documented.
  • EPL (extensor pollicis longus) tendon rupture occurs late due to attrition over the displaced fracture.
  • Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS) is a known painful complication.

Explanation of Other Options:

Non-union (Option A): Rare but documented late complication of Colles fracture.

EPL tear (Option B): Known late complication due to attrition over displaced fragments.

CRPS (Option C):Sudeck's dystrophy, a chronic pain condition, is a late complication of wrist fractures.

questions.text: A patient sustains a fall on an outstretched hand and develops pain and tenderness over the lateral elbow. Imaging shows the fracture pattern seen in the given image. Which classification system is used to describe this type of injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mason classification is used for radial head fractures, especially those involving the articular surface of the radial head. The classification is based on the degree of displacement and comminution:

Explanation of Other Options:

Bado classification (Option A): Used for Monteggia fracture-dislocations, which involve fracture of the ulna shaft with dislocation of the radial head. It classifies these injuries into four types based on the direction of radial head dislocation.

Mayo classification (Option B): Applies to olecranon fractures, categorising them into three types (I to III) based on displacement, stability, and comminution, with subtypes A (non-displaced/stable) and B (unstable/comminuted).

Malone classification (Option C): Used for distal radius fractures. It helps describe intra-articular vs. extra-articular involvement, degree of displacement, and stability, though it's less commonly used than the Frykman or AO classification.

questions.text: Bankart's lesion involves the avulsion of the labrum from which part of the glenoid?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bankart's lesion refers to the detachment of the glenoid labrum from its antero-inferior aspect, typically due to anterior dislocation of the shoulder. This region is the most stressed during dislocation, especially in younger patients or during high-energy trauma.

  • Bankart lesion: Avulsion of the antero-inferior labrum of the glenoid rim, typically seen in recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation.
  • Hill-Sachs lesion: Impression fracture of the postero-lateral humeral head due to impaction against the glenoid rim.
  • Reverse Bankart lesion: Avulsion of the postero-inferior glenoid rim, seen in recurrent posterior dislocations.
  • Reverse Hill-Sachs lesion: Antero-medial humeral head defect in recurrent posterior dislocation.

Explanation of Other Options:

Anterior lip of the glenoid (Option A): Incomplete; the lesion is more accurately located at the antero-inferior part of the rim rather than the broad anterior region.

Superior lip of the glenoid (Option B): Not the typical site of avulsion in Bankart lesion; more associated with SLAP (Superior Labrum Anterior to Posterior) tears.

Antero-superior lip of the glenoid (Option C): Again, not the typical site; Bankart involves the lower (inferior) anterior portion.

questions.text: Which of the following is the last secondary ossification centre to appear around the elbow joint?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The elbow has six secondary ossification centres that appear in a specific chronological order, remembered by the mnemonic CRITOE:

  • C - Capitellum - 2 years
  • R - Radial head - 4 years
  • I - Internal (medial) epicondyle - 6 years
  • T - Trochlea - 8 years
  • O - Olecranon - 10 years
  • E - External (lateral) epicondyle - 12 years

Thus, the lateral epicondyle is the last to appear, typically at around 12 years of age.

Explanation of Other Options:

Capitellum (Option A): First to ossify; appears at around 2 years.

Trochlea (Option B): Appears around 8 years; not the last to ossify.

Medial epicondyle (Option C): Ossifies by around 6 years; appears earlier than the trochlea and lateral epicondyle.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was suddenly lifted by the arm and started crying, refusing to move the elbow. The forearm is held pronated with the elbow slightly flexed. No signs of swelling or deformity are present. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pulled elbow (nursemaid's elbow) is a subluxation of the radial head due to sudden longitudinal traction on the forearm, especially in children aged 1-5 years. The annular ligament slips over the head of the radius and gets trapped.

  • Classic history: child lifted or swung by hand → sudden onset of pain
  • Position: forearm pronated, elbow slightly flexed; the child avoids using the arm
  • X-rays are usually normal
  • Reduction is by supination and flexion or by extension and pronation
  • A palpable "click" may be felt during reduction, followed by immediate relief

Explanation of Other Options:

Elbow dislocation (Option A): Rare in this age group; usually follows significant trauma and is associated with swelling and deformity.

Supracondylar humerus fracture (Option B): Most common elbow fracture in children, but presents with swelling, pain, and deformity, not a painless pronated forearm.

Radial head dislocation (Option D): Seen in Monteggia fracture-dislocation; not isolated in young children without fracture.

choices.text: Occurs in children between 5-10 years of age
Tardy ulnar nerve palsy can be seen

questions.text: All of the following are true about lateral condyle fracture of the humerus in children, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cubitus varus occurs following malunion of supracondylar fractures, not lateral condyle fractures. Lateral condyle fractures are more commonly associated with cubitus valgus due to growth arrest and nonunion.

  • Age group: Typically affects children aged 5-10 years.
  • Mechanism: Often caused by varus stress with the elbow extended, leading to avulsion of the lateral condyle.
  • Complication - Nonunion: Common due to the pull of extensor muscles, especially with displacement >2 mm.
  • Cubitus valgus: Results from asymmetric growth arrest; progressive deformity with time.
  • Tardy ulnar nerve palsy: Chronic cubitus valgus can lead to stretching of the ulnar nerve, causing delayed-onset palsy.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents to your clinic with the deformity shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The deformity seen in the image shows cubitus varus - a medial deviation of the forearm in relation to the arm, giving a "gunstock" appearance. This is a classical sequela of a malunited supracondylar fracture of the humerus in children.



Explanation of Other Options:

Colles fracture (Option A): Produces dinner fork deformity at the wrist, not the elbow.

Lateral epicondyle fracture (Option B): Leads to cubitus valgus if non-union occurs; not varus.

Medial epicondyle fracture (Option C): May cause ulnar nerve symptoms; does not cause varus deformity.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child had sustained an elbow fracture 4 years ago following a fall. He now presents with tingling and numbness over the ring and little fingers. Which of the following is the most likely fracture the child sustained?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child is presenting with tardy ulnar nerve palsy - a delayed onset ulnar nerve dysfunction classically due to progressive cubitus valgus deformity. The most common cause of tardy ulnar nerve palsy is non-union of the lateral condyle humerus fracture in childhood.

Explanation of Other Options:

Supracondylar humerus fracture (Option A): Common in children but leads to cubitus varus, not valgus; does not cause tardy ulnar palsy.

Elbow dislocation (Option C): May cause immediate ulnar nerve palsy but not tardy onset. Also rare in young children.

Pulled elbow (Option D): Refers to radial head subluxation, typically in toddlers; not associated with ulnar nerve issues.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents after a fall directly on the point of his elbow. X-ray reveals a displaced intercondylar fracture of the distal humerus. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In displaced intercondylar humerus fractures, the two condyles are separated due to axial loading by the olecranon. These injuries are unstable and intra-articular, requiring anatomical realignment and rigid fixation for optimal functional recovery.



Explanation of Other Options:

Close reduction and internal fixation (Option A): Not suitable due to the intra-articular nature and instability of the fracture.

Casting and immobilisation (Option B): Appropriate only for undisplaced fractures; displaced ones need surgical fixation.

External fixation (Option D): Not routinely used unless associated with open fractures or severe soft tissue damage.

choices.text: Flexion-type supracondylar fracture with radial head and elbow dislocation
Coronoid fracture, olecranon fracture, and elbow dislocation
Coronoid fracture, radial head fracture, and elbow dislocation

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the "terrible triad" injury of the elbow?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The "terrible triad" of the elbow is a severe injury pattern resulting from valgus, axial, and posterolateral rotatory forces. It is characterised by:

  • Radial head fracture
  • Coronoid process fracture
  • Posterior elbow dislocation

This injury disrupts the bony architecture and lateral collateral ligament complex, resulting in elbow instability. Surgical treatment aims to restore joint congruity and ligament stability.

Explanation of Other Options:

Flexion-type supracondylar fracture with radial head and elbow dislocation (Option A): Not a recognised combination for the terrible triad.

Anterior olecranon fracture dislocation (Option B): Olecranon fractures with anterior dislocation form a different injury pattern.

Coronoid fracture, olecranon fracture, and elbow dislocation (Option C): Rare combination; olecranon is not part of the classical terrible triad.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents after falling on an outstretched right arm. His X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The X-ray reveals a transverse fracture of the proximal third of the ulna with anterior dislocation of the radial head - characteristic of a Monteggia fracture-dislocation.


Explanation of Other Options:

Bowing fracture (Option A): Plastic deformation without visible cortical break. Common in children, especially with the greenstick pattern, but no dislocation.

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation (Option B): Fracture of the distal radius with dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint, not proximal ulna.

Greenstick fracture (Option C): Incomplete fracture of cortex; common in children, usually midshaft, but does not show dislocation of radial head.

questions.text: A 25-year-old football player presents after his finger got caught in an opponent's jersey during a tackle. He is unable to flex the tip of his ring finger. On examination, the distal interphalangeal joint is held in extension and does not flex actively. What is the most likely tendon injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a classic presentation of Jersey Finger, which is caused by the avulsion of the Flexor Digitorum Profundus (FDP) tendon from the base of the distal phalanx.


Explanation of Other Options:

Flexor digitorum superficialis (Option A): Inserts into the middle phalanx; injury here would spare DIP joint function.

Extensor digiti minimi (Option C): Extensor of the little finger, not related to flexion.

Extensor indicis (Option D): Extensor of the index finger, not involved in DIP flexion.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with pain and swelling of the left elbow following a fall onto an outstretched hand. On examination, the elbow is swollen and tender. The three-point bony relationship between the medial epicondyle, lateral epicondyle, and olecranon is maintained. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In a normal elbow flexed to 90°, the three bony points-medial epicondyle, lateral epicondyle, and olecranon - form an isosceles triangle. This three-point relationship helps distinguish supracondylar fractures from other elbow injuries.

  • In supracondylar humerus fractures, the fracture lies above the condyles, so the relationship between the three points is maintained.
  • In fractures involving the condyles (lateral/medial) and elbow dislocations, this triangle is disrupted.

questions.text: A depressed intra-articular fracture of the lunate fossa of the distal radius is also known as a:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A die-punch fracture is defined as a depressed intra-articular fracture of the lunate fossa of the distal radius. It typically results from axial loading, often in high-energy injuries, and the articular surface must be perfectly reduced and fixed for optimal joint function.

questions.text: What mechanism most likely led to this injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A Smith's fracture is an extra-articular distal radius fracture with volar angulation of the distal fragment, most commonly caused by a fall onto a flexed wrist.

Explanation of Other Options:

Axial loading of the carpus (Option A): Causes injuries to carpal bones (e.g., scaphoid fracture), not the distal radius.

Axial loading of the forearm (Option B): Associated with Monteggia or Galeazzi fracture-dislocations.

Falling onto an outstretched hand (Option D): Causes Colles fracture, not Smith fracture; Colles has dorsal angulation.

choices.text: Volar angulation with radial deviation occurs
It may lead to gunstock deformity due to malunion
It is associated with dorsal angulation

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the fracture shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a Colles' fracture of the distal radius, which is characterised by dorsal angulation and impaction of the distal fragment, without articular surface involvement.

Explanation of Other Options:

Volar angulation with radial deviation occurs (Option A): Incorrect. This is a feature of the Smith fracture, not the Colles. Colles fracture has dorsal angulation with radial deviation.

It is an intra-articular fracture (Option B): Incorrect. Classic Colles' fracture is extra-articular, although variants may rarely involve the articular surface.

It may lead to gunstock deformity due to malunion (Option C): Incorrect. Gunstock deformity (cubitus varus) is a complication of supracondylar humerus fracture, not distal radius fractures.

questions.text: Putti-Platt's operation for shoulder instability involves overlapping and tightening of which muscle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Putti-Platt operation involves overlapping (double breasting) and tightening of the subscapularis tendon to limit external rotation and anterior translation of the humeral head.

This prevents the arm from assuming the vulnerable abduction + external rotation position, which commonly causes recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation.

  • It is a non-anatomical procedure, mainly of historical interest now, due to the restriction of external rotation and poor functional outcomes.
  • Modern anatomical repairs (e.g., Bankart repair) or bone block procedures (e.g., Latarjet) are preferred today.

Explanation of Other Options:

Supraspinatus (Option A): Abduction initiator; not targeted in instability procedures.

Coracobrachialis (Option B): Involved in shoulder flexion; part of the conjoint tendon in Latarjet but not involved in Putti-Platt.

Teres minor (Option D): External rotator; located posteriorly; not surgically manipulated in shoulder stabilisation procedures.

choices.text: It is the most commonly fractured carpal bone
The initial X-ray may not show the fracture clearly
Tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox is a key clinical finding

questions.text: Which of the following statements about scaphoid bone fracture is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All three statements are correct: scaphoid is the most frequently fractured carpal bone, often missed on initial X-rays, and presents with characteristic snuffbox tenderness.

(Other options are ruled out)

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented to the casualty after an RTA. He had sustained a fracture as shown in the X-ray given below. On examination, he is also unable to dorsiflex his wrist. What is this fracture known as?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Injury to the radial nerve due to a spiral fracture of the distal third of the humerus is characteristic of the Holstein-Lewis fracture.

  • This fracture pattern involves a spiral fracture of the distal one-third of the humeral shaft.
  • Radial nerve palsy is a common complication due to the proximity of the nerve in this region, presenting as wrist drop or inability to dorsiflex the wrist.
  • It accounts for about 7.5% of humeral shaft fractures.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed via X-ray, showing a typical spiral configuration of the distal third.

Explanation of Other Options:

Thurston Holland sign (Option A): Triangular metaphyseal fragment seen in Salter-Harris type II fractures, not related to the humerus or radial nerve.

Essex Lopresti fracture (Option B): Involves radial head fracture with interosseous membrane injury and DRUJ disruption, unrelated to humeral shaft or wrist drop.

questions.text: Sprengel's deformity is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sprengel's deformity refers to a congenital elevation of the scapula due to failure of its descent during embryogenesis. It is the most common congenital shoulder anomaly.

Explanation of Other Options:

Absence of clavicle (Option A): Seen in cleidocranial dysostosis, not in Sprengel's deformity.

Acromioclavicular dislocation (Option B): A traumatic injury, not a congenital anomaly.

Recurrent dislocation of the shoulder (Option D): Usually due to capsulolabral injury; not a developmental defect.

questions.text: In an extension-type supracondylar humerus fracture, which anatomic structure is most likely to be interposed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Median nerve is the most commonly involved structure due to its anatomical course anterior to the distal humerus, especially in extension-type supracondylar fractures, which often displace posteriorly.

Explanation of Other Options:

Brachialis muscle (Option A): Can be interposed, but is less common than the median nerve in causing mechanical block.

Radial nerve (Option B): More commonly injured in posteromedial displacement but not typically interposed.

Ulnar nerve (Option D): More commonly injured in flexion-type supracondylar fractures.

questions.text: French osteotomy is used in the treatment of -
questions.solution:
Explanation:

French osteotomy (lateral close wedge) is the most commonly performed surgery for cubitus varus, a cosmetic deformity that commonly follows malunion of supracondylar humerus fracture in children.

  • Cubitus varus, also known as a 'gunstock deformity', is the most common complication of supracondylar fracture humerus, due to malunion.
  • It is called gunstock because the deformity resembles a rifle gunstock. o The three static deformities of cubitus varus are (all with respect to the distal fragment)-i) Extension, ii) Medial rotation, iii) Varus (coronal tilt). All three components should be corrected during the initial reduction of the fracture; otherwise, cubitus varus deformity results.
  • Cubitus varus is only a cosmetic deformity with no functional impairment of the elbow. The treatment of choice is corrective supracondylar osteotomy. Surgery is deferred until skeletal maturity due to the fear of recurrence of deformity if surgery is done before skeletal maturity. Osteotomy methods are-
    • Lateral close wedge osteotomy (French or modified French)
    • Medial open wedge osteotomy (King's osteotomy)
    • Derotation osteotomy

Explanation of Other Options:

Cubitus valgus (Option B): May result from nonunion of lateral condyle fracture; usually managed with medial epiphysiodesis or corrective osteotomy, but not French osteotomy.

Coxa vara (Option C): Deformity of the femoral neck-shaft angle; managed with valgus-producing osteotomy.

Coxa valgus (Option D): Rare condition, not treated with French osteotomy.

questions.text: Bone loss in the Hill-Sachs lesion occurs in which part of the humeral head?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Hill-Sachs lesion is a compression fracture occurring on the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head as it impacts the anterior glenoid rim during anterior dislocation.

  • Occurs during anterior shoulder dislocation, especially when recurrent
  • Leads to a groove or indentation in the posterolateral humeral head
  • Detected on X-ray (flattening) or MRI (depression in posterosuperior head)
  • May coexist with a Bankart lesion (labral tear of the glenoid rim)
  • Lesion size correlates with the risk of recurrence

Explanation of Other Options:

Posterior (Option A): Incorrect; the lesion is not limited to the posterior surface.

Anterior (Option C): Incorrect; the anterior surface is not involved in Hill-Sachs but is relevant in reverse Hill-Sachs lesions (posterior dislocations).

Anteroinferior (Option D): Incorrect; this refers to the Bankart lesion site on the glenoid, not the humeral head.

choices.text: Inability to touch the opposite shoulder
Paresthesia of the upper lateral arm

questions.text: All can be seen in anterior shoulder dislocation except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The anterior axillary fold becomes lower, not elevated, in anterior shoulder dislocation.

  • The clinical features of anterior dislocation of the shoulder are
    • Abduction, external rotation deformity
    • Flattening of the shoulder
    • Duga's test
      • Inability to touch the opposite shoulder
    • Hamilton ruler test
      • A straight ruler placed on the lateral aspect of the arm will be able to touch the acromion and the lateral condyle of the humerus.
    • Callaway test
      • The vertical circumference around the axilla is increased
    • Bryant's test
      • Anterior axillary fold at a lower level
    • If there is an associated Axillary N injury
      • There will be paresthesia of the lateral aspect of the arm. This is called the 'regimental badge' sign.

Explanation of Other Options:

Inability to touch the opposite shoulder (Option A): Positive Duga's test; typical in anterior dislocation.

Flattening of the shoulder (Option C): Due to anterior displacement of the humeral head.

Paresthesia of the upper lateral arm (Option D): Seen due to axillary nerve injury.

questions.text: Following the dislocation of the shoulder, a patient develops weakness of elbow flexion and sensory loss over the lateral forearm. Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Elbow flexion weakness with sensory loss over the lateral forearm points to musculocutaneous nerve injury, which supplies the biceps, brachialis, and lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm.

  • This occurs due to the palsy of the Brachialis and Biceps, which are supplied by the Musculocutaneous nerve. The Lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm is also a branch of the Musculocutaneous Nerve, hence the sensory loss.
  • The Musculocutaneous Nerve is the second most commonly injured nerve in shoulder dislocation after the Axillary Nerve.

Explanation of Other Options:

Radial nerve (Option A): Causes wrist drop; not primarily involved in elbow flexion or lateral forearm sensation.

Axillary nerve (Option B): Commonly injured; causes deltoid paralysis, not elbow flexion weakness.

Median nerve (Option D): Affects forearm flexors and hand; no sensory loss over lateral forearm.

choices.text: Fracture of the neck of the humerus

questions.text: A 50-year-old man had an epileptic seizure 2 days ago, which was treated at a local hospital. He now has pain in his right shoulder and keeps his arm and forearm close to his abdomen. He is unable to abduct or externally rotate his shoulder. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Inability to abduct and externally rotate the shoulder following a seizure strongly suggests posterior dislocation of the shoulder.

  • Posterior shoulder dislocation is rare (<2% of shoulder dislocations) but commonly follows seizures or electric shock due to internal rotation and adduction forces.
  • Key clinical findings include:
    • The arm is held in adduction and internal rotation
    • Loss of external rotation and abduction
    • May appear normal on AP X-ray (commonly missed diagnosis)

Explanation of Other Options:

Anterior dislocation of the shoulder (Option A): Most common type; presents with abduction and external rotation deformity, not seen post-seizure.

Greater tuberosity fracture (Option C): May occur with dislocations but is not commonly associated with seizure or fixed internal rotation posture.

Fracture of the neck of the humerus (Option D): Pain and swelling are present, but classical posture and movement restriction seen in dislocation are absent.

questions.text: Which of the following is a test for posterior shoulder instability?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Jerk test is a specific provocative manoeuvre used to identify posterior shoulder instability, where posterior subluxation or dislocation is reproduced with axial loading in a flexed and internally rotated arm.

  • The common tests for various shoulder instabilities are given below.

Explanation of Other Options:

J sign (Option A): Not related to the shoulder; refers to the patellar tracking abnormality in the knee.

Jobe's test (Option B): Evaluates the supraspinatus tendon for rotator cuff tear, not instability.

Sulcus sign (Option D): Indicates inferior or multidirectional shoulder instability, not posterior.
